verses.kjv: Then Agrippa said unto Paul, Thou art permitted to speak for thyself. Then Paul stretched forth the hand, and answered for himself:
verses.ct: Then Agrippa said to Paul, "You have permission to speak on your own behalf." So Paul raised his hand and began his defense:

verses.kjv: I think myself happy, king Agrippa, because I shall answer for myself this day before thee touching all the things whereof I am accused of the Jews:
verses.ct: "King Agrippa, I consider myself fortunate to be making my defense before you today regarding all the charges the Jewish leaders have brought against me,

verses.kjv: Especially because I know thee to be expert in all customs and questions which are among the Jews: wherefore I beseech thee to hear me patiently.
verses.ct: especially since you are thoroughly familiar with all the customs and disputes among the Jewish people. So I ask you to listen to me patiently.

verses.kjv: My manner of life from my youth, which was at the first among mine own nation at Jerusalem, know all the Jews;
verses.ct: All the Jewish people know how I have lived from my youth, first among my own people and then in Jerusalem.

verses.kjv: Which knew me from the beginning, if they would testify, that after the most straitest sect of our religion I lived a Pharisee.
verses.ct: They have known me for a long time and could confirm, if they were willing, that I followed the strictest group within our religion — I lived as a Pharisee.

verses.kjv: And now I stand and am judged for the hope of the promise made of God unto our fathers:
verses.ct: Now I am on trial because of my hope in the promise that God made to our ancestors.

verses.kjv: Unto which promise our twelve tribes, instantly serving God day and night, hope to come. For which hope’s sake, king Agrippa, I am accused of the Jews.
verses.ct: This is the very promise that our 12 tribes are hoping to see fulfilled as they earnestly worship God day and night. Yet it is because of this hope, King Agrippa, that the Jewish leaders are accusing me.

verses.kjv: Why should it be thought a thing incredible with you, that God should raise the dead?
verses.ct: Why do any of you consider it impossible that God raises the dead?

verses.kjv: I verily thought with myself, that I ought to do many things contrary to the name of Jesus of Nazareth.
verses.ct: I myself was once convinced that I should do everything in my power to oppose the name of Jesus of Nazareth.

verses.kjv: Which thing I also did in Jerusalem: and many of the saints did I shut up in prison, having received authority from the chief priests; and when they were put to death, I gave my voice against them.
verses.ct: That is exactly what I did in Jerusalem. With authority from the chief priests, I threw many of God's people into prison, and when they were sentenced to death, I cast my vote against them.

verses.kjv: And I punished them oft in every synagogue, and compelled them to blaspheme; and being exceedingly mad against them, I persecuted them even unto strange cities.
verses.ct: I had them punished repeatedly in synagogue after synagogue, trying to force them to speak against their faith. I was so furious with them that I even hunted them down in foreign cities.

verses.kjv: Whereupon as I went to Damascus with authority and commission from the chief priests,
verses.ct: On one such mission, I was traveling to Damascus with the authority and approval of the chief priests.

verses.kjv: At midday, O king, I saw in the way a light from heaven, above the brightness of the sun, shining round about me and them which journeyed with me.
verses.ct: At noon, King Agrippa, while I was on the road, I saw a light from heaven brighter than the sun, blazing all around me and my traveling companions.

verses.kjv: And when we were all fallen to the earth, I heard a voice speaking unto me, and saying in the Hebrew tongue, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me? it is hard for thee to kick against the pricks.
verses.ct: We all fell to the ground, and I heard a voice speaking to me in the Hebrew language, saying, 'Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? You are only hurting yourself by fighting against this.'

verses.kjv: And I said, Who art thou, Lord? And he said, I am Jesus whom thou persecutest.
verses.ct: I asked, 'Who are you, Lord?' And he replied, 'I am Jesus, the one you are persecuting.

verses.kjv: But rise, and stand upon thy feet: for I have appeared unto thee for this purpose, to make thee a minister and a witness both of these things which thou hast seen, and of those things in the which I will appear unto thee;
verses.ct: Now get up and stand on your feet. I have appeared to you for a specific reason — to appoint you as my servant and witness, both of what you have already seen and of what I will reveal to you in the future.

verses.kjv: Delivering thee from the people, and from the Gentiles, unto whom now I send thee,
verses.ct: I will rescue you from your own people and from the Gentiles. I am sending you to them

verses.kjv: To open their eyes, and to turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan unto God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins, and inheritance among them which are sanctified by faith that is in me.
verses.ct: to open their eyes, to turn them from darkness to light and from the dominion of Satan to God, so that they may receive forgiveness of sins and a share in the inheritance among those who are set apart by faith in me.'

verses.kjv: Whereupon, O king Agrippa, I was not disobedient unto the heavenly vision:
verses.ct: So then, King Agrippa, I did not disobey that vision from heaven.

verses.kjv: But shewed first unto them of Damascus, and at Jerusalem, and throughout all the coasts of Judaea, and then to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God, and do works meet for repentance.
verses.ct: Instead, I proclaimed first to those in Damascus, then in Jerusalem, then throughout the entire region of Judea, and also to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God, living in ways that demonstrate genuine repentance.

verses.kjv: For these causes the Jews caught me in the temple, and went about to kill me.
verses.ct: This is why the Jewish leaders seized me in the temple and tried to kill me.

verses.kjv: Having therefore obtained help of God, I continue unto this day, witnessing both to small and great, saying none other things than those which the prophets and Moses did say should come:
verses.ct: But God has helped me to this very day, and so I stand here testifying to everyone, both ordinary and influential people, saying nothing beyond what the prophets and Moses predicted would happen —

verses.kjv: That Christ should suffer, and that he should be the first that should rise from the dead, and should shew light unto the people, and to the Gentiles.
verses.ct: that the Christ would suffer, that he would be the first to rise from the dead, and that he would bring light both to the Jewish people and to the Gentiles."

verses.kjv: And as he thus spake for himself, Festus said with a loud voice, Paul, thou art beside thyself; much learning doth make thee mad.
verses.ct: While Paul was making this defense, Festus shouted, "Paul, you've lost your mind! All your studying has driven you insane!"

verses.kjv: But he said, I am not mad, most noble Festus; but speak forth the words of truth and soberness.
verses.ct: But Paul replied, "I am not insane, most excellent Festus. What I am saying is true and completely reasonable.

verses.kjv: For the king knoweth of these things, before whom also I speak freely: for I am persuaded that none of these things are hidden from him; for this thing was not done in a corner.
verses.ct: The king is well aware of these matters, and I can speak openly to him about them. I am confident that none of this has escaped his attention, because these events did not take place in secret.

verses.kjv: King Agrippa, believest thou the prophets? I know that thou believest.
verses.ct: King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know that you do."

verses.kjv: Then Agrippa said unto Paul, Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian.
verses.ct: Agrippa said to Paul, "You nearly have me convinced to become a Christian."

verses.kjv: And Paul said, I would to God, that not only thou, but also all that hear me this day, were both almost, and altogether such as I am, except these bonds.
verses.ct: Paul answered, "Whether it takes a little or a lot, I pray to God that not only you but everyone listening to me today would become what I am — except for these chains."

verses.kjv: And when he had thus spoken, the king rose up, and the governor, and Bernice, and they that sat with them:
verses.ct: Then the king stood up, along with the governor, Bernice, and everyone sitting with them.

verses.kjv: And when they were gone aside, they talked between themselves, saying, This man doeth nothing worthy of death or of bonds.
verses.ct: After they stepped aside, they discussed the matter among themselves, saying, "This man has done nothing that deserves death or imprisonment."

verses.kjv: Then said Agrippa unto Festus, This man might have been set at liberty, if he had not appealed unto Caesar.
verses.ct: Agrippa told Festus, "This man could have been released if he had not appealed to Caesar."
